automotiveThis Week's Highlights:
How to Drive EconomicallyGas Prices Explained
How MapQuest WorksHow GPS Receivers Work
How Interstate Highways are Numbered 
Summer Getaway Edition - Planning a summer road trip? Heading to relatives' for the July 4th holiday? In this edition of the HowStuffWorks Automotive newsletter, we help you get your car in shape for that road trip and plan your summer getaway. For inspiration, check out our 
image gallery of
scenic drives.   This week's trivia question:Suppose you are stopped at a railroad crossing for one minute. Which consumes more gas: keeping the engine running, or turning off and restarting your car? 
Find out here   
 
How to Drive Economically - With gas prices soaring, the cost of a summer road trip is on the rise. But there are a few things you can do -- before and during your trip -- to save money. Learn how tire inflation and regular vehicle maintenance affect your gas mileage and get tips for fuel-efficient driving. 
    This week's video:
Gas Prices Explained - Why are gas prices higher than they have been in the past? Learn about the factors that affect the price at the pump and find out what causes fluctuations in crude oil prices in this video from HowStuffWorks and Petro Canada. 
     Also at HowStuffWorks:
 

How MapQuest Works - If you're planning
a driving trip, chances are you'll use an online mapping service such as
MapQuest to chart your route. Learn how MapQuest works and why errors sometimes
happen.
 
How GPS Receivers Work - Having a GPS receiver in your car can make you feel a lot more confident when traveling. Learn about the amazing technology behind GPS and read reviews of GPS devices. 
 
Is there any rhyme or reason to how U.S. interstate highways are numbered? When I-95 hits metropolitan Washington, D.C., it becomes the famous Beltway, signed I-495. North of the metro area, it becomes I-95 again. Find out how U.S. interstates are numbered.
